comment.text: The "LinkExpireAfter" translation key is used to display the message "The link will expire after <1>{{date}}</1>" in various UI elements, such as buttons and dropdowns. This text provides context for users about how long a shareable link remains active. It appears in components like the Expired ComboBox and Share helpers.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The translation "Link <1>{{date}}</1> sonra başa çatacaq" doesn't accurately convey the meaning of "The link will expire after <1>{{date}}</1>". It literally translates to 'Link will end after [date].'  A more accurate translation would incorporate the phrase 'will expire'.
The Azerbaijani translation lacks equivalent formatting tags (e.g., <1> and </1>).
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: If the tags need to be preserved for some reason, include equivalent tags in Azerbaijani. Otherwise, they should be removed.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The English phrase "expire" is better translated as "verfällt" or "wird ungültig" in this context rather than "abläuft". "Abläuft" typically implies a scheduled event, whereas the link's expiration is more about becoming invalid.

The English phrase 'after <1>{{date}}</1>' implies the link expires *on* the date specified, not *after* it. The Finnish translation 'Linkki vanhenee <1>{{date}}</1> jälkeen' literally translates to 'The link expires after <1>{{date}}</1> after', which is redundant and doesn't accurately convey the intended meaning. A better translation would reflect expiration *on* the date.

The Armenian translation 'Հղման ժամկետը կսպառվի <1>{{date}}</1>-ից հետո' literally translates to 'The link deadline will expire after <1>{{date}}</1>'. While understandable, it sounds awkward and less natural in Armenian. A more natural phrasing would convey the expiration *on* the date, rather than *after*.

The XML tags `<1>` are likely placeholders for a dynamic value. While the translation correctly preserves them, it is unclear if the Armenian output needs to mirror this precise formatting. Assuming they represent the 'LinkExpireAfter' key placeholder, ensure this is handled correctly during rendering.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Confirm the purpose and correct implementation of the `<1>` tags with the development team. The translation should be able to render properly with whatever tags are ultimately used.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Japanese translation lacks the 'です' particle at the end, which is essential for politeness and grammatical correctness when making a statement. While understandable without it, it is less natural.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: リンクの有効期限は<1>{{date}}</1>です

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Lao translation 'ເຊື່ອມຕໍ່ຈະໝົດອາຍຫຼັງຈາກ' while conveying the general meaning, can be improved for better flow and naturalness. A more accurate and common phrasing would be 'ເຊື່ອມຕໍ່ຈະໝົດເວລາຫຼັງຈາກ'. 'ໝົດອາຍ' translates more literally to 'run out of air' and isn't the typical way to describe link expiration.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: ເຊື່ອມຕໍ່ຈະໝົດເວລາຫຼັງຈາກ

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Latvian translation 'Saites derīguma termiņš beigsies pēc' is a bit overly formal and verbose for the simple English 'The link will expire after'. A more natural and concise translation would be 'Saites izbeigsies pēc'.

The HTML tags <1> and </1> are present in both the English and Latvian translations. While technically correct, they don't have a functional purpose in the context of a user interface and might be best removed to avoid unnecessary complexity.

The Romanian translation uses "după data" which literally translates to "after the date". It's more natural to say "după" alone when referring to a time period after which something expires. "După data" implies a specific date is the trigger, which isn't necessarily the intent.

The translation "සබැඳිය <1>{{date}}</1>ට පසු කල් ඉකුත් වේ" is a literal translation but doesn't flow naturally in Sinhala. A more natural phrasing would be something like "සබැඳිය <1>{{date}}</1> දින අවසානයේදී වලංගුභාවය නැතිවේ" or "සබැඳිය <1>{{date}}</1> දිනදී සකසNULL වේ".
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider revising to "සබැඳිය <1>{{date}}</1> දින අවසානයේදී වලංගුභාවය නැතිවේ" or "සබැඳිය <1>{{date}}</1> දිනදී සකසNULL වේ".

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Serbian translation 'Линк ће да истекне после <1>{{date}}</1>' translates literally to "The link will expire after..." which is grammatically correct, but a more natural and common phrasing in Serbian would be "Линк важи до <1>{{date}}</1>" (The link is valid until...).

The English phrase 'expire after' is not accurately translated. 'Sona erecektir' implies the link ends *on* the date, not *after* the date. A more accurate translation would convey 'after' the specified date.
The format tags (<1>{{date}}</1>) are replicated in the Turkish translation. While likely intentional, it's worth confirming this is the desired formatting in the Turkish context.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Confirm desired formatting of tags with Turkish stakeholders.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The English phrase "expire" is better translated as "закінчиться термін дії" (zakinchytysia termin dii) or "стане недійсним" (стане ne diisnym) to accurately convey the meaning of a link becoming invalid.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Посилання буде недійсним після <1>{{date}}</1> -> Посилання закінчить термін дії після <1>{{date}}</1> or Посилання стане недійсним після <1>{{date}}</1>

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The phrase 'expire after' is not directly equivalent to '后过期'. A more natural and accurate translation would be '将在...失效' or '将在...到期'.  '后过期' sounds slightly awkward.
